entry.content:
This post covers why I chose Jekyll to build my siteâ€”and why building with intention matters. You can build just for now, just for fun, or for the future youâ€™re proud of. Hopefully this offers a little clarity and a lot of encouragement along the way.

When I started building DataInsideData.com, I wasnâ€™t just picking a tool to publish blog posts.

I was choosing how I wanted the site to operate in production.

That distinction matters.

Jekyll isnâ€™t just a static site generator â€” itâ€™s a static-first operational model that fits naturally with DevOps/DevSecOps and GitOps thinking.

Let me walk you through why.

ğŸŒ± What â€œNo Databaseâ€ Really Means in Jekyll

At its core, Jekyll builds your entire website ahead of time.

Instead of generating pages on every request, Jekyll outputs plain files:

  • HTML
  • CSS
  • JavaScript
  • Images

Once built, those files are what get deployed.

In practice, that means

  • ğŸ˜® No database
  • ğŸ˜ No backend runtime
  • ğŸ‘ No server-side request processing

Traditional CMS (WordPress, Drupal)

Request â†’ Server â†’ Database â†’ Backend Logic â†’ HTML â†’ User
  • Content lives in a database
  • Pages are assembled on every request
  • Requires patching, monitoring, backups, and scaling

Jekyll

Build time â†’ Static files â†’ User
  • Content lives in Markdown files
  • Pages are generated once at build time
  • Hosting becomes dramatically simpler

ğŸ’¡ Mental model
Jekyll trades runtime complexity for build-time clarity.

â“Why This Matters (Especially for DevOps)

This design choice unlocks several benefits that matter a lot in production environments.

âš¡Speed

Static files load instantly.
There are no database queries and no server-side logic slowing things down.

ğŸ” Security

  • No database â†’ no SQL injection
  • No admin panel â†’ fewer attack vectors
  • No backend â†’ dramatically reduced surface area

ğŸ§© Simplicity

Your â€œdatabaseâ€ becomes:

  • Markdown files
  • YAML front matter
  • Folder structure

Thatâ€™s it.

ğŸ” Version Control

Your entire site lives in Git:

  • Branches
  • Pull requests
  • Code review
  • Rollbacks

This fits perfectly with GitHub-based workflows.

ğŸ’¸ Cost

Static hosting is often free or near-zero cost:

  • GitHub Pages
  • Netlify
  • Cloudflare Pages
  • S3 + CDN

For a business or solo founder, thatâ€™s huge.

ğŸ§± How Jekyll Organizes Content (Without the Chaos)

Jekyll gives you structure without forcing a CMS UI.

Hereâ€™s a simplified view of how content is organized:

.
â”œâ”€â”€ _posts/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ 2026-01-20-why-jekyll.md
â”œâ”€â”€ _pages/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ about.md
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ contact.md
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ privacy.md
â”œâ”€â”€ _projects/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ci-preview-setup.md
â”œâ”€â”€ _layouts/
â”œâ”€â”€ _includes/
â””â”€â”€ assets/

ğŸ“ Posts (_posts/)

Best for:

  • Blog articles
  • Tutorials
  • Build notes
  • Thought leadership

Named like:

YYYY-MM-DD-title.md

ğŸ“¦ Pages

Good for standalone pages like:

  • About
  • Contact
  • Legal pages
  • Landing pages
  • etc.

ğŸ—‚ï¸ Collections

Collections are where Jekyll really shines.

They let you create custom content types, such as:

  • Case studies
  • Labs
  • Datasets
  • Documentation

Defined once in _config.yml:

collections:
  projects:
    output: true
  case_studies:
    output: true

This gives you Content Management System (CMS)-like power without a CMS.

ğŸ› ï¸ From Content to Production (Build Flow)

Hereâ€™s the lifecycle at a high level:

Markdown + Templates
        â†“
   Jekyll Build
        â†“
     _site/
        â†“
   GitHub Pages / Content Delivery Network (CDN)

The _site/ folder is the final artifact.

Once itâ€™s built:

  • Nothing mutates
  • Nothing executes
  • Nothing queries a database

Thatâ€™s what gets deployed.

ğŸš€ Why This Fits DevOps (and GitOps) Thinking

Jekyll naturally encourages:

  • Immutable infrastructure
  • Build once, deploy everywhere
  • No mutable runtime state
  • Predictable, testable builds
  • CI/CD-first workflows

In other words:

ğŸ¯ Key insight
Youâ€™re not just building a website â€” youâ€™re building a pipeline.

This is exactly how modern infrastructure is designed.

ğŸŒŸ The Big Picture

Jekyll gives you:

  • The structure of a CMS
  • The security of static files
  • The discipline of DevOps
  • The flexibility of code

For DataInsideData.com, itâ€™s the foundation of a professional, scalable, and production-ready platform â€” without unnecessary complexity.

entry.content:
Series note:
This post covers the fastest possible path from zero to a running Jekyll site.
In the next post, Iâ€™ll show how I improved this scaffold with better structure, styling, and a production-ready workflow.

ğŸš€ A Beginner-Friendly Jekyll Tutorial for Those Interested in

  • learning how to design websites/blogs.
  • Building a site for work.
  • Building a living portfolio to showcase your evolving projects, professional development, etc.
  • Creating a testing/learning environment in order to practice HTML, CSS, JS, etc.
  • Practicing by implementing DevSecOps/DevOps concepts and methods in a real world development/production environment.
  • Or anything else that demonstrates your hands on technical knowledge.

Note: This tutorial is specifically For Windows Users. Weâ€™ll have an equivalent MacOS version in an upcoming postğŸ˜.

ğŸªœ These are the first steps before you actually begin building your awesome site

Installing jekyll

âœ” Step 1

  • navigate to RubyInstaller Downloads
  • if youâ€™re not sure about which version to use or new to jekyll?
    • jekyll recommends using Ruby+Devkit 3.4.X (x64) installer.
    • this version has the

      largest number of compatible gems and installs the MSYS2 Devkit alongside RUBY, so gems with C-extensions can be compiled immediately.

âœ” Step 2

  • use selected default options for installation
  • after installation finishes
    • click finish and the installer will automatically install the other dependencies
    • this happens because of the checked [âœ”ï¸]) check box on the installation wizard.
      • this executes/runs
     ridk install
    • and is needed for installing gems with native extnesions.
    • additional documentation can be found here RubyInstaller Documentation
      • From the options list, choose 3, MSYS2 and MINGW development toolchain
  • We need to open up the powershell (ps) command line interface (CLI) or command prompt (cmd), so we can check if the application has been installed correctly.
  • Simply click then type into the search tool located on the bottom task bar.

  • Open Windows Search Tool:

  • Now letâ€™s check if Ruby has been installed correctly by running.
ruby --version
  • you should see something similar to this:
ruby 3.4.8 (2025-12-17 revision 995b59f666) + PRISM [x64-mingw-ucrt]

âœ” Step 3

  • close out the terminal window and reopen so changes to the PATH environmemt are reflected.
  • Install Jekyll and Bundler using
gem intall jekyll bundler

âœ” Step 4

  • Now letâ€™s check if Jekyll has been installed correctly by running this command
jekyll -v

âœ” Step 5

  • If you want to update Jekyll for any reason, run the following command, for example to update your installation (remove brackets)
gem update --system [ add version number here ]

Congratulations on installing Ruby and Jekyll, you are now ready to create your blogğŸ¤“ğŸ˜

  • This section shows how to create a simple blog upon which you can then build your preferred awesome site.

1ï¸âƒ£ After installing the jekyll

gem intall jekyll bundler

2ï¸âƒ£ Create new jekyll site at ./myblog by running this command

jekyll new myblog

3ï¸âƒ£ Change directory to /myblog thusly

cd myblog

4ï¸âƒ£ Build the site and make it available on your local server

bundle exec jekyll serve

5ï¸âƒ£ Now browse to the following local web-address provided

http://localhost:4000 or something similar , by holding down ctrl on the keyboard and clicking the link to open the page in your default browser.

  • Or by copying the link and pasting it into your browser.

This tutorial is based on the Full Jekyll Documentation.

entry.title: ğŸš€ From Zero to Live: Setting Up My Jekyll Blog with GitHub Pages and AWS Route 53

link.title: ğŸš€ From Zero to Live: Setting Up My Jekyll Blog with GitHub Pages and AWS Route 53

entry.content:
Note: The AWS Route53 domain must be fully configured before using this method. Optionally one can use github pages address to render the blog/website.

In less than a week I went from zero to a fully deployed, professional blog at datainsidedata.com.

This wasnâ€™t just a â€œhello worldâ€ experiment. I wanted a lean, pro-grade stack for this project using:

âœ” Jekyll (static site generator)
âœ” GitHub Pages (free hosting)
âœ” AWS Route 53 (custom domain + DNS)

  • This post + video will show you exactly how I did it, what I learned, and how you can replicate (or improve) the setup for your business, nonprofit, or personal brand.
  • I provide a deep dive into building a blog using Minima theme.

ğŸ¥ Watch it here: [video coming soon!]

ğŸ› ï¸ My Stack

Tool Purpose
Jekyll Static site generator
GitHub Pages Free hosting for site
AWS Route 53 DNS + custom domain
VS Code Local development
datainsidedata.com My custom domain

ğŸ’¡ Why Jekyll Instead of Just HTML/CSS/JS?

When I started this, I asked myself: â€œWhy not just code a static site by hand?â€

Hereâ€™s why I chose Jekyll:

ğŸš€ 1. Built for Blogs

Jekyll was literally designed for blogs. It supports:

  • Markdown posts
  • Categories & tags out of the box
  • Auto-generated archive & pagination
  • Clean permalinks like /2026/07/15/my-jekyll.html

With pure HTML/CSS/JS, Iâ€™d have to hand-code all of that.

ğŸ’ 2. Minimalist and Professional

Jekyll doesnâ€™t need a heavy backend (no PHP, no databases).
Itâ€™s just static filesâ€”fast, secure, and deploys beautifully on GitHub Pages.

ğŸ§° 3. Gems and Themes = Less Reinventing the Wheel

  • The Minimal Mistakes theme gave me a professional design instantly.
  • Gems like jekyll-feed and jekyll-seo-tag handle RSS feeds & SEO for me.

Pure HTML/CSS/JS? Iâ€™d be reinventing:
âœ” Sitemap.xml
âœ” RSS feed
âœ” SEO metadata
âœ” Responsive layouts

ğŸ’¨ 4. One Command â†’ Whole Site Built

Jekyll lets me run:

bundle exec jekyll build

â€¦and it renders all posts, layouts, and assets into the _site folder, ready for deployment.

In a pure static setup, Iâ€™d manually copy/paste and keep track of every link. ğŸ˜¬

ğŸ“¦ Initial Setup: Jekyll + Minimal Mistakes Theme

1ï¸âƒ£ Install Ruby, Bundler, and Jekyll

gem install bundler jekyll

2ï¸âƒ£ Create a new Jekyll site

jekyll new datainsidedata-website
cd datainsidedata-website
bundle install

3ï¸âƒ£ Add the Minimal Mistakes theme for a clean, professional look

4ï¸âƒ£ Configure _config.yml

  • Set site title, description, author info
  • Enable pagination & pretty permalinks
  • Set up categories & tags

ğŸ“‚ Project Structure (before build):

_data/
_includes/
_layouts/
_pages/
_posts/
_site/  (auto-generated by Jekyll build)

ğŸŒ Custom Domain with GitHub Pages + AWS Route 53

ğŸ—‚ Private + Public Repo Workflow

Since GitHub Pages doesnâ€™t serve from private repos unless you pay for Pro:

  1. Private repo: did-site-private (holds full Jekyll source)
  2. Public repo: did-site-public (hosts built site for Pages)

ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¾â€ğŸ’» Local workflow:

# Build site
bundle exec jekyll build

# Push to public repo
cd _site
git init
git remote add origin https://github.com/dataeden/did-site-public.git
git add .
git commit -m "Deploy"
git push -u origin main

ğŸ·ï¸ AWS Route 53 DNS Setup

âœ… Add A records:

185.199.108.153
185.199.109.153
185.199.110.153
185.199.111.153

âœ… Add a CNAME file in the public repo:

datainsidedata.com

âœ… Verify domain with GitHub:
Add a TXT record in Route 53 like:

_github-pages-challenge.datainsidedata.com  TXT  "abc123xyz456"

âœ… Enable HTTPS in GitHub Pages after TLS cert provision.

âš¡ Sneak Peek: Automating with GitHub Actions (No More _site Pushes!)

Hereâ€™s the workflow Iâ€™m planning:

ğŸ“‚ .github/workflows/deploy.yml

name: Build and Deploy Jekyll Site

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main  # Watch for changes in private repo

jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - name: Checkout private repo
      uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Setup Ruby + Jekyll
      uses: ruby/setup-ruby@v1
      with:
        ruby-version: '3.1'

    - name: Install dependencies
      run: bundle install

    - name: Build site
      run: bundle exec jekyll build

    - name: Deploy to public repo
      uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
      with:
        github_token: $
        publish_dir: ./_site
        publish_branch: main
        destination_repo: dataeden/did-site-public

ğŸ¯ With this in place:

  • Push to did-site-private
  • GitHub Actions auto-builds & deploys to did-site-public
  • No more manual _site pushes ğŸš€

ğŸš¨ Lessons Learned

ğŸ’¥ _pages folder pain: Jekyll didnâ€™t respect links until I restructured pages.
ğŸ”¥ Custom nav bar: Built my own in bash _includes/header.html + _includes/nav.html.
ğŸ•’ DNS propagation: Patience and coffee are dev tools too.

ğŸ¯ The Result

âœ… Live at datainsidedata.com
âœ… Clean navigation, custom logo, HTTPS-secured
âœ… Learned Jekyll + DNS at a pro level

ğŸ“ Whatâ€™s Next?

âœ” Publish more posts (like this one!)
âœ” Add Google Analytics
âœ” Fully automate deploys with GitHub Actions
âœ” Share more dev journey content

ğŸ“º Watch the full video walkthrough â†’ [Coming soon!]
